newsitem.title: TAJIKISTAN: Tajik rebel retreats towards Uzbekistan-army.
newsitem.headline: Tajik rebel retreats towards Uzbekistan-army.

text.p: A rebel Tajik colonel fighting government forces has retreated towards the border with Uzbekistan, but his exact whereabouts were unknown, a government field commander said on Saturday.
Rebel Colonel Makhmud Khudoyberdyev had made the village of Chapayev, 20 km (12 miles) south of regional centre Kurgan Tyube in southwest Tajikistan, his base of operations.
But on Friday he retreated ahead of the arrival of government forces, said Colonel Usmon Murchayev, commander of the government's 11th Brigade.
"We entered the base without fighting because Makhmud Khudoyberdyev had left earlier, taking all hardware and people with him and moving toward Uzbekistan," he told Reuters.
Murchayev could not give Khudoyberdyev's exact whereabouts but said government forces had surrounded the rebel troops.
Interfax news agency, quoting the president's spokesman, said the rebel colonel had moved into a farm settlement 40 km (25 miles) from the Uzbek border.

Fighting erupted in the capital Dushanbe last week, only weeks after President Imomali Rakhmonov signed a peace agreement with Islamic opposition guerrillas aimed at ending four years of civil war in Tajikistan.
The guerrillas were not involved in the latest clashes, but Khudoyberdyev joined the fray, moving his brigade towards the capital last Saturday.
He appeared to suffer some defeats in four days of fighting and Rakhmonov said on Wednesday the colonel had been dismissed.
A new government commander, Seralisho Mirzoyev, on Saturday arrived in Kurgan Tyube, 110 km (70 miles) south of Dushanbe, another Khudoyberdyev stronghold they seized on Friday.
But he found his task of organising remaining local forces difficult as many had retreated with working military hardware alongside the rebel colonel.
On Saturday a few government tanks rode around Kurgan Tyube, one flying a victorious red flag. Cars stayed off the street, shops were closed, and people seemed afraid to leave their homes.
Khudoyberdyev's home in Kurgan Tyube was looted on Friday, and it remained open on Saturday, with possessions scattered across its rooms.
